title-group.article-title: Low-Entry-Point Method for Chorda Tympani Nerve Preservation during Middle Ear Surgery

body.p: Taste disturbance is not an uncommon complication of middle ear surgery.1,2 To reduce chorda tympani nerve (CTN) injury, it is important to know the most likely location of this nerve. However, no studies have formally analyzed the location of the CTN. This is the first study that attempts to assess the frequency distribution of CTN location, represented as the hours on the face of a clock, to provide a safer surgical approach for middle ear surgery.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Between June 2009 and November 2009, 38 patients undergoing middle ear surgery at our hospital were examined to determine the exact location of the CTN. The hospital institutional review board approved the study protocol. We rendered the whole eardrum and annulus as a clock, with 12 o’clock as the lateral process of the malleus, and the CTN location was described in reference to the bony annulus as the “hour” on the clock (Figure 1). Postauricular incision was performed in all patients. Subsequently, a low-entry-point method (LEPM) was used to identify the middle ear and the CTN. The point where the CTN traversed the bony annulus was recorded as described above. A basic or extended atticotomy approach was used in every case to assess the ossicular chain.

caption.p: (A) The right eardrum and annulus rendered as a clock and a sketch of the low-entry-point technique: using the Rosen needle to enter the middle ear at 6 to 7 o’clock in the right ear (5-6 o’clock in the left ear), the eardrum is elevated radially (direction of the arrows) but not circularly to find and expose the chorda tympani nerve (CTN). (B) The left eardrum. The percentages for each “hour” are shown.

sec.title: Low-Entry-Point Method
sec.p: The low-entry-point method is used for the precise identification of the CTN. After elevating the tympanomeatal flap medially to the bony annulus, we penetrated the posterior-lower part of the fibrous annulus (between 6 and 7 o’clock in the right ear and between 5 and 6 o’clock in the left ear) with a Rosen needle. From that point, we elevated the eardrum radially. That is, we moved the tip of the Rosen needle toward the lateral process of the malleus, parallel to the presumed CTN position, but not directly along the upper bony annulus. If the nerve was not found, we made another entry point 1 o’clock superior to the previous one through the fibrous-bony annulus junction to look for the CTN, creating another radially directed window (Figure 1). Because the route of the CTN was usually pointed superiorly toward the malleus neck, the direction of the dissection was always kept inferior-to-superior. Once the CTN was located, the multiple windows were connected and the annulus was elevated more rapidly by a Gimmick elevator.

sec.title: Outcome Measures
sec.p: The percentage of CTNs found at each location and the rate of CTN sacrifice were calculated. We also analyzed age, sex, the presence of cholesteatoma, the side of surgery, preoperative air-bone gap, the type of tympanoplasty, CTN location, and whether mastoidectomy was performed. All the data were analyzed by χ2 test using SPSS version 17.2 (SPSS, Inc, an IBM Company, Chicago, Illinois).

sec.title: Patients and Outcomes
sec.p: For the 38 patients analyzed, the mean age was 39 years (range, 7-76 years). The mean air-bone gap prior to surgery was 31.63 dB (range, 13-57 dB). Patients’ characteristics are presented in Table 1.

sec.title: CTN Location
sec.p: The exit point of the CTN from the bony annulus was, in the right ear, at the 10-, 9-, 8-, and 7-o’clock positions in 20%, 70%, 5%, and 5%, respectively. For the left ear, it was at the 2-, 3-, and 4-o’clock positions in 17%, 72%, and 11%, respectively.

sec.title: CTN Preservation Rate
sec.p: The overall preservation rate of the CTN with LEPM was 86.8%. Differences between groups in age, sex, preoperational air-bone gap, or tympanoplasty type, which may influence CTN preservation, were not significant. The only significant factor in terms of CTN preservation was the presence of cholesteatoma. In patients with and without cholesteatoma, the rate of CTN preservation was 66.7% and 96.2%, respectively (P < .05).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of this study demonstrate that the CTN emerges from the bony annulus mostly from the posterior to the upper posterior side. Only in 10.5% of the patients does the nerve emerge from the lower posterior quadrant. No significant differences existed between the 2 sides.

The CTN may be damaged as the surgeon separates the eardrum from the bony annulus. Therefore, the surgeon should choose the safest point at which to enter the middle ear and then carefully elevate the eardrum toward the most common location of the CTN. To accomplish this, it is critical to be familiar with the most frequent locations of this nerve. This is the first article formally analyzing the location of the CTN. Our study supports the usefulness of the low-entry technique, and future studies comparing traditional vs LEPM techniques will be helpful to validate these preliminary findings. Our CTN preservation rate (86.8%) is higher than the rates reported in 3 recent studies, which were 79%, 55%, and 65.6%.3-5

The main weaknesses of this article are the small patient number and no questionnaire designed for subjective symptoms. No dysgeusia was reported in our follow-up data, but there might be bias in that every patient may not be asked about presence of dysgeusia without a formal questionnaire. We think that a more detailed questionnaire, designed to evaluate the postoperative dysgeusia, might be helpful in the future.

In conclusion, to avoid damaging the CTN, we recommend LEPM as a reliable method during middle ear surgery, by using the Rosen needle to enter the middle ear at 6 to 7 o’clock in the right ear and 5 to 6 o’clock in the left ear and elevating the eardrum radially but not circularly with the same instrument. Cholesteatoma was the only factor influencing CTN preservation.
